Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Apple Yield Mapping using Computer Vision
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is the practical deployment of a computer-vision based yield estimation system in fruit orchards. This will provide fruit farmers with a useful tool in planning their harvest and sales, as well as in managing the long-term health of their plants. This will potentially reduce the inherent risk in fruit growing, thereby improving the affordability and availability of fresh fruit in the US. Better certainty may particularly help small growers, because they have less existing capability to manage risk. Furthermore, by allowing adoption of precision agriculture techniques techniques to high value crops, this project may help save water and contribute to reduction of runoff pollution from fertilizer and chemicals.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses the problem of vision-based fruit detection and mapping of fruit, for purposes of yield mapping. The research objectives are to improve the commercial usability and robustness of existing yield-mapping approaches, so that they can be applied in production fruit orchards. The anticipated technical results of this project include demonstration of useful yield mapping of apples, in a variety of real world production orchard environments, in a variety of weather and lighting conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Yield mapping is critical for fruit growers: an accurate estimate is enormously beneficial to sales operations, harvest time logistics, and plant management. Currently, yield mapping is performed manually, in a difficult, laborious process which is prone to sampling and counting error. If our proposed system allows automation of yield mapping, it will help fruit growers to improve their growing and harvesting processes, allowing them to sell better fruit at higher prices while using less resources. By bringing improved certainty to harvest quantity and timing, it will also improve the efficiency of the entire fruit supply chain, making fresh fruit more readily available in stores, at more consistent prices.


Our objective is to develop a practical, low hardware cost, easy to use computer vision system that will allow fruit growers to automatically and accurately map the number, size, and color of fruit in their orchards. In the short term, our fruit mapping technologies will enable growers and shippers to plan for harvest operations, sales and shipping. Over time, our technologies, coupled with predictive models, will enable long term yield forecasting and provide data for phenotyping and general farm management.


While conceptually simple, the task of using video to count fruit on trees in an orchard row is challenging in practice. Identification by color is difficult because of variability in lighting, shadows, and specularities. Identification and counting by shape is difficult because of occlusions by leaves and other fruit. For this project we tackled the problem of fruit counting as two subproblems of detection and reconstruction. Detection is knowing in a single image frame where the fruit are located. Reconstruction is correlating the fruit across multiple frames, together with estimating the motion of the camera, to obtain a consistent estimate of the fruit positions and sizes.


During this NSF SBIR Phase I project, Farm Vision Technologies made great strides towards development of a minimum viable product that measures fruit on trees in orchards. We solved significant problems in hardware selection, and we are confident in our most recent hardware topology. We iterated over a range of fruit detecting and fruit counting subsystems, and the most recent vision pipeline operates reliably in a range of environments with no human intervention. Although there remains technical work to be done to bring a commercial product to market, we are confident that we can solve the remaining challenges in Phase II.
